Summary: During a demonstration flightç a U.S. Army flyer flown by Orville Wright nose-dived into the ground from a height of approximately 75 feetç killing Lt. Thomas E. Selfridge who was a passenger. This was the first recorded airplane fatality in history.  One of two propellers separated in flightç tearing loose the wires bracing the rudder and causing the loss of control of the aircraft.  Orville Wright suffered broken ribsç pelvis and a leg.  Selfridge suffered a crushed skull and died a short time later.
First U.S. dirigible Akron exploded just offshore at an altitude of 1ç000 ft. during a test flight.
The first fatal airplane accident in Canada occurred when American barnstormerç John M. Bryantç California aviator was killed.

The airship flew into a thunderstorm and encountered a severe downdraft crashing 20 miles north of Helgoland Island into the sea. The ship broke in two and the control car immediately sank drowning its occupants.
Hydrogen gas which was being vented was sucked into the forward engine and ignited causing the airship to explode and burn at 3ç000 ft..
Crashed into trees while attempting to land after being shot down by British and French aircraft.

Type: de Havilland DH-18 / Farman F-60 Goliath
Summary: A midair collision occurred in poor visibility approximately 18 miles north of Beauvaisç France. This was the  first commercial midair collision in aviation history. Two killed on the de Havillandç five on the Faman F-60.
All seventeen aboard were Chinese nationals.
Crashed while on a flight from Toulonç France to Algiersç Algeria.  The last known radio contact reported the ship nearly out of fuel and battling strong winds.  Struck by lightning.

Shortly after taking offç witnesses observed a puff of white smoke after which the plane nose-dived into the ground. Fuel starvation. Captain Stewart and seven passengers were killed in an attempted forced landing.
Crashed in poor weather.

The Shenandoah was flying over Southern Ohio when she abruptly encountered violent atmosphericonditions (thunderstorms). Powerful air currents buffeted her so severely that her crew was unable to maintain control. Rising rapidly above her pressure heightç then falling and rising againç her hull structure was overstressed amidshipsç breaking the airship in two. Shenandoah's external control car and two engine cars fell freeç carrying the dirigible's commanding officer and several other men to their deaths. The stern section came down nearbyç while several men were able to fly the bow section to ground as a free balloon.
